title: Do these sentences mean the same: 'If I had studied, I would have probably passed.', 'If I studied, I would probably pass.'? - Quora

response.answer_text: They don’t mean the same thing. The first example is talking about an event that has happened, the conditional in the past. (Grammar wonks call this the “third conditional”.) The implication of this sentence is that (at a specific point in the not necessarily recent past) the speaker took and exam, failed it, and acknowledges (in retrospect) that s/he didn’t study enough for it. The second example is talking about an event that is at some point in the real or imagined (but by implication near) future. (Grammar wonks call this the “second conditional”.) The implication of this sentence is that the speaker is considering whether or not to take an exam, and weighing up the amount of work involved in relation to the probable outcome. It has a more speculative tone to it because the use of the conditional word would makes it sound as if (a) it’s not certain that the speaker is going to take the exam; and (b) is not sure of the outcome if s/he does. If you say “If I study, I will pass” that has more of a definite feeling. (Grammar wonks call this the “first conditional”.) This means: I’m going to take an exam (it’s a reasonably certain event in the predictable future); and provided I put enough effort in, it seems likely that I will succeed. Grammar wonks also refer to the “Zero conditional” which is used when describing when one thing is the logical consequence of another but doesn’t have any (or much) unpredictability: “If you drop a glass out of a third-floor window onto concrete, it will break.”

No, they are not the same. The first talks about an even in the past. “If I had studied, I would have passed” = “On the condition that I studied, I would have (i.e., in the past) passed.” It could mean either that the speaker did not study, took the exam, and did not pass, OR, it could mean that the speaker did not study and, more importantly, did not take the exam (eg., “If I had studied, I would have passed, but I got called away two weeks before the exam”). The second talks about an even that is still in the future. “If I studied, I would pass” = I have not yet taken the test yet. I know that it is within my ability to pass it, on the condition that I study.

Not the same. “If I had studied, I would have passed.” = In the past, I had the chance to take a test and enter a prestigious university, The test wasn’t hard, but it required a certain amount of study. I didn’t study. Therefore I failed the test.” “If I studied, I would pass.” = I haven’t taken the test yet. The test isn’t difficult. I don’t know if I will study or not. That is really up in the air.

Not even close! The 1st one is positioned after a test which was failed, and gives the excuse for the failure as not having studied —- IF I HAD (in the past before the test) studied, I believe I would have passed —- but I didn’t, so I failed. The 2nd is positioned before a test or tests and opines that you will have a high likelihood of passing, but only if you study before the test.

Would have probably passed is what you say after the test. In the second sentence, you are implying that either you have not taken the test yet, or you are talking about a pattern of not passing due to lack of studying. Hope this helps!
The first sentence describes something that has already happened in the past. The second one is about an unreal situation or an upcoming event.
The first one is correct. It is also in the past. If doesn't apply here because you didn't study, so therefore you can't be sure that you would pass. Probably is just a guess.
First sentence is looking on the past, second is present-tense or explaining to someone else. Meaningwise they are the same but will be perceive differently.
The fist refers to a past non-success, while the second refers to a confident prediction of the future.
